wikipedia_page.main: Jane Johnson (born 1960) is an English writer of books for adults and children and fiction book editor. As a writer she has used the pseudonyms Gabriel King, jointly with M. John Harrison, and Jude Fisher, as well as her real name.

response: * Jane Johnson (born 1960), HarperVoyager
Beginning with The Wild Road during 1996 and concluding with Nonesuch (2001), he co-wrote four associated fantasies about cats with Jane Johnson, using the pseudonym "Gabriel King".

| 1992 || The Course of the Heart || novel. UK: Gollancz, Flamingo.  The 2004 Night Shade Books edition (first US edition) adds the short story "The Great God Pan" which Harrison describes in a note as a 'rehearsal' for the novel. The UK ed (Gollancz, 1992) is dedicated "To JJ (=Jane Johnson) with love" although this dedication is not reproduced in the 2004 edition.
| 1997 || The Wild Road || as Gabriel King, written in collaboration with Jane Johnson
| 1998 || The Golden Cat || as Gabriel King, written in collaboration with Jane Johnson
| The Knot Garden || as Gabriel King, written in collaboration with Jane Johnson
| 2001 || Nonesuch || as Gabriel King, written in collaboration with Jane Johnson

Ismail ibn Sharif is mentioned in chapter 11 of Voltaire's Candide. The character of the sultan in the novel "The Sultan's Wife" by Jane Johnson is based on Moulay Ismaïl. In Marguerite Henry's King of the Wind "Sultan Mulai Ismael, Emperor of all Morocco" sends six Arabian horses to Louis XV, "the boy-King of France."
* He appeared as a main character in the novel Court of Lions (2017) by Jane Johnson.

* One of the main supporting characters in Jane Johnson's Eidolon trilogy is a young girl selkie called She Who Swims the Silver Path of The Moon (Silver for short) who becomes close with the main hero, Ben Arnold, when he rescues her from the evil Doddman's pet shop.
